Reception given by Palestinian ambassador
   Pyongyang, April 29 (KCNA) -- Shaher Mohammed Abdlah, Palestinian ambassador to Korea, gave a reception at the embassy on April 28 to mark the 67th anniversary of the Korean People's Army (KPA).   Invited were general Jong Chang Ryol, colonel general Ji Ki Son and officers of the KPA.   Speeches were made at the reception.

Anti-DPRK war bill passed in Japan
    Pyongyang, April 29 (KCNA) -- The Japanese house of representatives on April 27 okayed "emergency legislation" for implementation of the updated "guidelines for Japan-U.S. defense cooperation", according to a news report from Tokyo.   The legislation came to realise reinvasion ambition of the Japanese reactionaries who are following the U.S. war policy of overseas aggression in accordance with the updated "guidelines" made public in 1997.   From content and scope of application it aims primarily at the DPRK.   The legislation proves that the "guidelines" for a war of aggression on the DPRK have, in fact, come into force, deserving caution.

articles.title: Plan to undertake anti-"government" struggle declared
articles.content:
Plot to suppress worker's strike in S. Korea
   Pyongyang, April 29 (KCNA) -- The chief executive of South Korea, at a "State Council" Tuesday, slandered worker's strikes for vital rights as "illegal violence" and branded them as "enemy of democracy," according to a radio report from Seoul.    He threatened that "illegal strikes would not be tolerated."   This fully reveals his criminal intention to crack down upon worker's strikes.   As for illegality, it is the anti-national criminal deeds of the self-proclaimed "government for the people" which has driven workers to poverty and death.   The "government" and the rulers are entirely to blame for the strikes.   Nevertheless, the chief executive slandered worker's strikes and blackmailed strikers, revealing his dirty colors as the enemy of workers.

articles.content:
Sports circles brisk at schools
   Pyongyang, April 29 (KCNA) -- Sports contests are now in full swing among school sports circle members in all counties, cities and provinces of Korea.   Their technical actions in ball games and field and track and gymnastic events are attracting the attention of experts.   The sports contests are held among primary and secondary schools every year with a view to building up the physical strength of millions of schoolchildren and train them steadily to be sports reserves.   Schools are attaching importance to specializing sports events. They are selected to suit their specific conditions.
Promising students are involved in sports circles.   
   It was in April 1974 that schools began to introduce specialization.   More than 10,000 sports circles with about 410,000 members have been organized at primary and senior middle schools across the country.    Circle activities help students acquire sports technique of at least one event and contribute to developing sports.   Sports circles have produced state sports reserves numbering about 30,000 over the past 25 years.   Among them are some 30 people's and merited sportsmen and sportswomen and  hundreds of masters of sports.   Sports circles throughout the country serve as state sports reserve-training centers.
